comments:
This course is a continuation of Chemistry 101. The second term stresses the
thermodynamic approach to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction
rates and mechanisms. It includes special topics in chemistry.
Students reported that this course could be “very interesting,” but also that it
tended to be “dry.” A biology major wrote that “it provided some chemical insight into
biological systems and in general was more applicable than CHEM101,” making it a
useful course.
Professor Saven was described as “occasionally humorous,” but for the most part
was “disorganized, monotonous and unclear.” Students also said he “did not know how
to teach concepts in an appropriate way.” Many found his lectures to be exceedingly
difficult to follow or understand, and students were forced to only use the book to study.
Additionally, students said Professor Saven was unable “to cover everything on the
syllabus” due to the pace of the lecture. They did note, however, that he was very
“knowledgeable.”
Many students complained that there were not enough practice problems outside
of homework, which made tests “too difficult.” They also tended to be much harder than
the material covered in class.
